exam_papers.title: 2025年6月大学英语四级考试真题（一）
exam_papers.description: 2025年6月大学英语四级考试真题（第一套），包含写作、听力、阅读理解和翻译四个部分

exam_sections.directions: Suppose your university is seeking students' opinions on the necessity of making College Chinese a compulsory course. You are now to write an essay to express your view. You will have 30 minutes to write the essay. You should write at least 120 words but no more than 180 words.

In this section, you will hear three news reports. At the end of each news report, you will hear two or three questions. Both the news report and the questions will be spoken only once. After you hear a question, you must choose the best answer from the four choices marked A), B), C) and D). Then mark the corresponding letter on Answer Sheet 1 with a single line through the centre.

In this section, you will hear two long conversations. At the end of each conversation, you will hear four questions. Both the conversation and the questions will be spoken only once. After you hear a question, you must choose the best answer from the four choices marked A), B), C) and D). Then mark the corresponding letter on Answer Sheet 1 with a single line through the centre.

In this section, you will hear three passages. At the end of each passage, you will hear three or four questions. Both the passage and the questions will be spoken only once. After you hear a question, you must choose the best answer from the four choices marked A), B), C) and D). Then mark the corresponding letter on Answer Sheet 1 with a single line through the centre.

In this section, there is a passage with ten blanks. You are required to select one word for each blank from a list of choices given in a word bank following the passage. Read the passage through carefully before making your choices. Each choice in the bank is identified by a letter. Please mark the corresponding letter for each item on Answer Sheet 2 with a single line through the centre. You may not use any of the words in the bank more than once.
exam_sections.passage_content:
Psychologists have long been interested in how we construct our identities and the sorts of strategies that we use to present ourselves in society. New findings suggest that the kinds of ___26___ and strategic self-presentation behaviour we see in adults appear at a much younger age than ___27___ known.

Research shows that a child's awareness of social standing comes from adults. Like grown-ups, kids want to be ___28___ by those they admire. Interactive experiences may provide opportunities for children to learn about what ___29___ a desirable reputation and the kinds of strategies that are effective for ___30___ a good reputation in their social environment.

Five-year-olds aren't just aware of their reputations, they also behave strategically to alter their outward image. They will ___31___ their behaviour in order to appear moral or socially good in the eyes of key observers. While we know that adults use a large variety of attributes to manage and create impressions, we don't yet know whether children ___32___ and use the fact that different attributes are valuable at different times to different ___33___ . It's important for us to further consider where in this process children succeed in controlling their reputation and where they ___34___ .

A question to think about is, "What happens even earlier than age five?" Children don't just show up to the first day of kindergarten and have the idea of reputation pop ___35___ into existence. The logical question to ask is, "What happens even earlier?"

exam_sections.directions: In this section, you are going to read a passage with ten statements attached to it. Each statement contains information given in one of the paragraphs. Identify the paragraph from which the information is derived. You may choose a paragraph more than once. Each paragraph is marked with a letter. Answer the questions by marking the corresponding letter on Answer Sheet 2.
exam_sections.passage_content:
A. Recently, a leading design federation in the UK warned that the UK could face a creative skills shortage, after the latest figures revealed a drop of almost 10 percent in students studying Design and Technology. These figures showed that the number of pupils that sat exams in Design and Technology fell 10 percent from 204,788 to 185,279 last year.

B. Chief executive John Kampfner of the Creative Industries Federation thinks that this drop in figures has worrying implications for the skills pipeline in Britain's hugely successful arts and creative industries. He said, "We already have skills shortages in many jobs such as animation (动画制作) and special effects." He added: "Engineering, which requires a similar mix of creative and technical skills, also has recruitment problems."

C. Many other designers and architects have expressed concern over the future supply of home-grown talent for UK firms, and industry bodies have pointed out that there has been a lack of roots-level support. However, if these designers had visited the Design Museum shop in London earlier this year their fears may have been eased. With £10 to spend, they could have bought a fascinating children's toy called "Dazzle Racer". An automotive cylinder(圆柱体), it included a wind-up, elastic (有弹性的)-band-powered mechanism, minimal parts, all 100 percent recycled and lots of stickers. It was good fun, simple, eye-catching and very original.

D. Well you'd expect the Design Museum to commission and make some interesting items, but this one was different. Designed by a group of six Year 9 and Year 10 boys from Finchley Catholic High School, the toy was the winning entry in the museum's 2015 Design Ventura competition, which brings the business of design to life for students aged 13 to 16 by challenging them to develop a new creative, sustainable and commercially feasible product for the Design Museum shop and attracts hundreds of entries nationwide.

E. "We did Design Ventura in my previous school," says Liam Hourican, Finchley Catholic High School's design technology curriculum leader. "Then when I changed schools four years ago, I introduced it here because it helps to develop so many skills."

F. The theme for last year's competition was "Move", and Hourican began with three groups working in lunch breaks and after school before selecting the group with the most innovative idea. Each participating school may submit just one proposal. "It's the taking part and doing the work which is important," he says. "And I never dreamt we'd win."

G. Catherine Ritman Smith, head of learning at the Design Museum, is expecting around 10,000 participants aged 13 to 16 to take part this year and says that the project — funded by Deutsche Bank as part of its youth engagement programme Born To Be — is the biggest event in the museum's calendar. "We started Design Ventura with around 800 young people in 2010 and it has grown steadily since," she says. "Teachers like it because the skills are all transferable and it helps to validate the value of design as a subject," she explains, telling me that nearly 600 schools have taken part so far.

H. So how does the competition work? A single-word theme is announced in the summer. This year it is "Change". Schools work with groups to produce imaginative design ideas for a product in simple materials that could sell for £10 in the Design Museum Shop. Participating schools then register by November and eventually submit their design idea. Along the way there is training and support for teachers and tutoring for students from designers. An additional bonus is when the winners see their design on sale in the spring of the following year.

I. Hourican and his pupils have happy memories of spending a whole day at the museum, having been selected as one of 10 shortlisted schools to present their idea to a panel of judges, including designer Jasper Conran. Then they worked with the Kin Design Studio in Shoreditch, met designers at their school and attended a lunch with Deutsche Bank employees. The students helped to make decisions and there were plenty of discussions — they changed the product's name, for example.

J. "One of the really useful things about this competition," says Hourican, "is that there's a commercial element because the product is going on sale for real and the boys had to learn about budgeting and marketing, as well as designing their game." Profits go to charity. "The winning team chooses where it wants the profits to go," says Ritman Smith. "The Finchley Catholic High School product raised about £1,000 for Great Ormond Street Hospital." Winning entries in past years have included a make-your-own cloth kit called Dove Bunting and a threefold, wallet-sized travel game with goals at each end, called Badotling.

K. It costs the schools nothing to participate in Design Ventura; the professional designers provide their services for free. Among them are architect Asif Khan, a Design Museum trustee who has worked as designer-in-residence at the museum, helping emerging architects. He has recently been commissioned to design the new Museum of London building in Smithfield.

L. Another is television presenter and interior designer Naomi Cleaver, who is one of the competition's judges. "I'm very keen to encourage young people," she says, observing that design brings together other subjects such as literature, art, history, geography and science. "Now that design education is limited in the curriculum, I'm all in favour of competitions such as Design Ventura, which helps to bring the standard curriculum to life," says Cleaver. "And the judging day is terrific fun. Some of these students are very imaginative. One group presented their idea in the form of a puppet show and we see some marvelous demonstration models. "I'm always impressed by the levels of confidence and the support the students get from their teachers."

M. Ritman Smith adds: "Design technology has become a tricky subject to make a case for, and we've heard of departments closing in some schools. We find that if pupils take part in Design Ventura in Year Nine it can be the trigger which leads them to opt for it at General Certificate of Secondary Education, so we are helping to keep alive something which is crucial to industry and entrepreneurship."

exam_sections.directions: There are 2 passages in this section. Each passage is followed by some questions or unfinished statements. For each of them there are four choices marked A), B), C) and D). You should decide on the best choice and mark the corresponding letter on Answer Sheet 2 with a single line through the centre.
exam_sections.passage_content:
Passage One

New research suggests that pandas may be at risk of dying out because they are too comfortable. Experts say too much happiness can stop the bears from searching for new mates.

Environmentalists have long believed that building roads or homes near the bears may threaten their survival by "reducing or fragmenting their natural habitats", The Times reported. But the new research suggests that a "modest degree of discomfort and fragmentation" may actually help preserve panda populations.

The research was conducted by scientists from Michigan State University. It concluded that pandas fail to wander off in search of new mates if they find their habitat too comfortable, resulting in a lack of vital genetic diversity.

For their study — outlined in a paper in the journal Conservation Biology — the team looked at genetic diversity and spread among a Chinese panda population. The ideal level of perfectly livable habitat was found to be only 80% of an area, with the remainder either too harsh or too affected by human activity.

The experts concluded that pandas should ideally "be happy enough to thrive, but not so content that they don't want to move around and find new mates".

Their conclusions about what The Guardian described as this "sweet spot" are in line with the so-called Goldilocks principle: that there can be just the right amount of something. The concept has been applied to a wide range of disciplines, from developmental psychology to economics and engineering.

Claudio Sillero, a professor of conservation biology at Oxford University, told the newspaper that the new findings could have implications beyond panda conservation.

"Most large animals that eat meat live in increasingly fragmented landscapes," said Sillero, who was not involved in the research. "It may well be that the messy nature of their relationship with human efforts induces more animals to scatter or travel further, and might result in greater genetic connectivity and enhanced population persistence."

The most recent count of pandas found that there were more than 1,800 left in the wild, putting them on the list of vulnerable, but not endangered, species.

Passage Two

With those born with natural talents, it feels as if they excel without really trying. But what about those of us who don't have a natural talent? We've been told all our lives that if you work hard, you too can succeed. But with the release of Angela Duckworth's Grit, we are given a new key to success.

"As much as talent counts, effort counts twice," says Duckworth in Grit. She introduces a new concept that talent may be overrated, and if you want real success, what you need is grit the perfect combination of passion and persistence. Even if you have natural talent it's nothing without grit.

Duckworth says grit is the difference between success and failure. A person who has grit is more likely to succeed than a person who does not. When we think about attaining success — whether it's landing that job or learning that new skill — our thoughts are immediately burdened by all the things we must first learn. If you want that new job, you have to learn the job skills, then the interview skills, then the dress part — and you must be perfect at all of them. Grit is different because it tells us that perfection isn't the goal.

Grit lifts the unreasonable expectations off our shoulders. Grit tells us that the door is open wider than we first thought possible. Grit allows us to redefine our goals. Think about it: what's something you've always wanted to do, but gave up because you "don't have the skills for it"? What's something you love but aren't good at?

The real workings of grit are to have sustainable passion and continue to try. Effort means more than your natural ability. Even if you haven't mastered a skill, grit tells you that you can still succeed if you can transform your passion into action. In a way, Duckworth is giving new hope to people who have shut the doors on their dreams. She is saying it is possible that you can accomplish anything. If at first you fail, then try one more time with grit.

exam_sections.directions: For this part, you are allowed 30 minutes to translate a passage from Chinese into English. You should write your answer on Answer Sheet 2.
exam_sections.translation_content: 被誉为"杂交水稻(hybrid rice)之父"的袁隆平和他的科研团队克服重重困难,研发出了一种超级杂交水稻。这项技术获得了举世公认的巨大成功。通过这项技术的应用,水稻抗旱抗病能力更强,能适应不同的气候和土壤条件,产量可提高20-30%。超级杂交水稻营养丰富,口感更佳。目前,这项技术已经在许多国家得到广泛应用,为全球粮食安全做出了重大贡献。
exam_sections.translation_requirements: 请将以下中文段落准确翻译成英文，注意语法正确和表达流畅

exam_questions.question_text: Write an essay to express your view on the necessity of making College Chinese a compulsory course.
exam_questions.analysis: 写作题目，需要学生就大学语文是否应该设为必修课阐述观点
exam_questions.explanation: 考查学生的议论文写作能力，包括观点阐述、论证支持和结论总结

exam_questions.question_text: How did Tariq make corn taste better?
exam_questions.options: ["A) By slapping some butter on it.", "B) By enhancing its nourishment.", "C) By growing it in South Dakota.", "D) By cooking it in vegetable oil."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻开头提到，当7岁的塔里克在玉米穗上涂抹一些黄油时，一切都改变了。他知道玉米本身味道不错，但黄油让它更美味。由此可知，选项A为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'Everything changed for 7-year-old Tariq when he slapped some butter on an ear of corn. He knew it tasted good, but butter made it better.'

exam_questions.question_text: Why were Tariq and his family invited to South Dakota?
exam_questions.options: ["A) To introduce their corn to tourists.", "B) To attend an honorary ceremony.", "C) To share experience with other corn growers.", "D) To exhibit their corn at the state's Corn Palace."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻后半部分提到，塔里克和他的家人受邀前往南达科他州，参加在该州玉米宫举行的荣誉仪式。故选项B为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'Tariq and his family were invited to South Dakota to attend the honorary ceremony at the state's Corn Palace.'

exam_questions.question_text: What did Jordan Jax and Tarod Goodman do according to a news release?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Stole mail several times.", "B) Forged postal keys illegally.", "C) Attacked postmen on multiple occasions.", "D) Broke a number of postal collection boxes."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻中多处提到两人涉嫌多次盗窃邮件，故选A。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'The arrests were in connection with a string of mail thefts...' 和 'the pair stole mail on multiple occasions using a postal key'

exam_questions.question_text: What do Jordan Jax and Tarod Goodman face?
exam_questions.options: ["A) A sentence for life.", "B) Loss of all their possessions.", "C) Twenty-three years' hard labor.", "D) Up to fifteen years in prison."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻末尾提到，贾克斯和古德曼因盗窃邮件罪，每人面临最高五年的联邦监禁，因持有邮政钥匙，每人面临最高十年的联邦监禁。由此可知，两项罪责加起来，联邦监禁时长共计15年，选项D为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'Jax and Goodman each face up to five years in federal prison in the mail thefts and up to ten years for possession of the postal key.'

exam_questions.question_text: Why has the clothing industry come under attack?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It escapes regulation and misleads consumers.", "B) It ignores economically feasible recycling options.", "C) It creates waste and severely impacts the environment.", "D) It produces clothes affordable only to a tiny minority."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻中提到，最近，服装行业因制造严重危害环境的废弃物问题而备受指责。由此可知，选项C为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'Recently, the clothing industry has come under attack for creating a waste problem with serious environmental consequences.'

exam_questions.question_text: Why did the researchers put forth such policies as production tax?
exam_questions.options: ["A) To cut consumers' expenses in buying quality clothes.", "B) To enable the whole fast-fashion industry to be sustainable.", "C) To incentivize manufacturers to be more consumer-friendly.", "D) To urge manufacturers and consumers to reduce waste."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻中提到，针对服装行业造成的严重的环境问题，研究人员提出了一系列政策建议，旨在激励制造商和消费者增强废弃物意识。由此可知，选项D为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'The researchers put forth policy contributions... to incentivize both manufacturers and consumers to be more waste conscious.'

exam_questions.question_text: What should be done first to eliminate the harm caused by the clothing industry?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Recognizing the impact on consumers.", "B) Identifying the source of the problem.", "C) Abandoning the current business model.", "D) Establishing powerful regulatory bodies."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。新闻后面部分提到，为了制定有效的政策以遏制服装业对环境的影响，找出供应链中问题的根源至关重要。因此，为消除服装行业带来的危害，首先应找出问题根源所在，选项B为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 新闻中提到：'In order to devise effective policies to curb the environmental impact of the clothing industry, it is important to identify the source of the problem in the supply chain.'

exam_questions.question_text: Why is the woman complaining?
exam_questions.options: ["A) The city's rush-hour traffic is intolerable.", "B) She cannot avoid rush-hour traffic.", "C) The local government is inefficient.", "D) The city is too big to move around easily."]
exam_questions.analysis: 主旨大意题。对话开头女性就抱怨这个城市的交通高峰期间简直要把她逼疯了，所以答案是A项。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话开头：'Rush hour in this city is killing me.'

exam_questions.question_text: What does the woman suggest doing?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Upgrading subway carriages.", "B) Increasing the number of bus routes.", "C) Air conditioning the city's subway.", "D) Learning from other big cities."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。在对话中，女士提出当地政府可以帮忙改善高峰时段的交通状况，比如地铁系统可以装空调，所以答案是C项。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'Well, for example, the subway system could have air conditioning.'

exam_questions.question_text: What do we learn about the man from the conversation?
exam_questions.options: ["A) He suffers from rush-hour crowding too.", "B) He is fortunate to live very near to work.", "C) He takes a half-hour bus ride to work.", "D) He is going to move closer to his office."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。在对话中，男士提到自己坐公交车通勤，36路公交车从他家直达办公室，车程30分钟，而且不用换乘，所以答案是C项。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'Bus No. 36 goes straight from my house to the office. It's a 30-minute ride and I don't have to make any changes.'

exam_questions.question_text: What does the woman ask the man to do at the end of the conversation?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Recommend to her a good house near his office.", "B) Send her his housing agent's telephone number.", "C) Tell her exactly what kind of property to look for.", "D) Make sure the agent finds something good for her."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。在对话中，女士问男士是否可以把这位房产中介的电话号码发给她，所以答案是B项。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'Hmm, could you send me his number, please?'

exam_questions.question_text: What does the man say about Johnny?
exam_questions.options: ["A) He was remembered for the scar on his cheek.", "B) He received a heart operation a few days ago.", "C) He used to wear a sad face in school.", "D) He had some plastic surgery done."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。在对话开头，男士就告诉女士约翰尼做了整形手术，所以答案是D项。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话开头：'He had some plastic surgery done.'

exam_questions.question_text: What does the woman find puzzling?
exam_questions.options: ["A) The man's deep sympathy for Johnny.", "B) The man's use of the expression 'fixed'.", "C) The man's covering up of what happened.", "D) The man's good memory of his childhood."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。在对话中，当男士提到约翰尼把那道疤修复了，女士反问道："修复？什么意思啊？疤痕怎么能够复啊！"显然，这里她对"修复"这个表达感到困惑，所以答案是B项。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'Fixed? What do you mean? You can't fix a scar.'

exam_questions.question_text: What did the man think of Johnny's scar?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It gave him a noticeable smartness.", "B) It made him appear even more manly.", "C) It seemed to give him a certain uniqueness.", "D) It seemed to make up for his physical defects."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。在对话中，男士评价约翰尼的疤痕为他增添了个性……就像赋予了他某种独特性，所以答案是C项。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中提到：'In fact, I thought it added character... like it gave him a certain uniqueness.'

exam_questions.question_text: How could we describe the speakers' attitude towards Johnny's girlfriend?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Liberal.", "B) Hostile.", "C) Indifferent.", "D) Critical."]
exam_questions.analysis: 态度观点题。在对话中，女士指责约翰尼的女朋友太肤浅、太自私了，男士首先认同女士的看法，然后说约翰尼向女朋友妥协，简直是疯了。两位说话者的态度均带有对约翰尼女朋友明显的否定和批评，D项"批判的"符合语境。
exam_questions.explanation: 对话中女士说：'That's so superficial and selfish of her.' 男士回应：'You are right. So he is insane to give in to her like that.'

exam_questions.question_text: How did language come into being according to researchers?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Through deliberation.", "B) Through evolution.", "C) Through invention.", "D) Through collaboration."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章开头部分明确提到，研究人员认为语言并非被发明出来的，而是逐步进化而来的。选项B与文章表述一致，因此为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 文章中提到：'Researchers don't think language was invented; instead, they think it evolved.'

exam_questions.question_text: How did language start according to the first theory?
exam_questions.options: ["A) With people imitating sounds around them.", "B) With people interacting with animals close by.", "C) With people showing each other things nearby.", "D) With people trying to string sounds together."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章中提到，根据第一种理论，语言起源于人类发出不同的声音，大多是对周围事物的模仿，比如动物的叫声、大自然的声响以及工具的声音。选项A与文章内容一致，因此为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 文章中提到：'The first theory is that language started with people making different sounds, mostly imitating the things around them, like animal calls, nature sounds, and the sounds of tools.'

exam_questions.question_text: Why did people switch from gesturing to making sounds according to the more recent theory?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Making sounds can free one's hands for doing other things.", "B) Making sounds proves markedly easier than sign languages.", "C) Making sounds enables one to express their ideas more explicitly.", "D) Making sounds helps one communicate with people they can't see."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章最后提到，该理论认为，人们之所以转向发音交流，是因为大声说话能让人们在无法看到对方的情况下依然保持沟通。选项D与文章内容一致，因此为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 文章中提到：'The reason they switched to making sounds, the theory goes, is that talking out loud lets you communicate with someone even when you can't see them.'

exam_questions.question_text: How would people describe someone who shows off their social status according to new research?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Well disciplined.", "B) Quite confident.", "C) Somewhat selfish.", "D) Highly intelligent."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章开头部分提到，但新研究发现，人们认为炫耀社会地位的人更关心自身利益，而非帮助他人，即更关注自身利益，显得自私。选项C与文章内容一致，因此为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 文章中提到：'But new research found that people believe someone who shows off their social status cares more about benefiting themselves than helping others.'

exam_questions.question_text: When were participants more likely to choose someone who signaled their wealth or status?
exam_questions.options: ["A) When they wanted to have a competitive team member.", "B) When they were looking for a cooperative workmate.", "C) When they found collaboration essential to them.", "D) When they were seeking someone to help them."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章中间部分提到，实验表明，当参与者在寻找竞争型团队成员时，却更倾向于选择炫耀财富或地位的人。选项A与文章内容一致，因此为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 文章中提到：'But participants were more likely to choose that person when they're looking for a competitive team member.'

exam_questions.question_text: What should people do when sharing their wealth and status online?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Avoid frightening competitors.", "B) Make clear their social goal.", "C) Adopt persuasive strategies.", "D) Consider the consequences."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章最后提到，人们可以轻松地向大量受众分享自己的财富和地位，但需要考虑后果，因为这既可能吸引他人，也可能传递自私的信号。选项D与文章内容一致，因此为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 文章中提到：'People can easily share their wealth and status to large audiences, but they need to consider the consequences.'

exam_questions.question_text: What can we see in the oldest cave paintings?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Much evidence of humans capturing animals.", "B) More images of animals than humans.", "C) Fewer images of buildings than animals.", "D) Little proof of human fascination with animals."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章开头提到，在已发现的最古老洞穴壁画中，有些距今可达4万年，其中动物的图像比人类图像更多。选项B与文章内容一致，因此为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 文章中提到：'Of the oldest cave paintings discovered, some are up to 40,000 years old, and there are more images of animals than humans.'

exam_questions.question_text: What do we learn about the first-known collections of animals?
exam_questions.options: ["A) They were open to the public.", "B) They were primarily native.", "C) They were kept by royalty.", "D) They were hardly injured."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章中提到，已知最早的动物收藏由皇室持有，且不向公众开放。选项C与文章内容一致，因此为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 文章中提到：'The first-known collections were held by royalty and were not open to the public.'

exam_questions.question_text: What might be the reason the Egyptian Queen created the zoo?
exam_questions.options: ["A) To enable the public to watch animals close by.", "B) To introduce to Egyptians animals from Punt.", "C) To protect the endangered animals.", "D) To show off her riches and power."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章中间部分提到，埃及女王哈特谢普苏特建造动物园的原因尚不清楚，但可能是为了炫耀她的财富与权力。选项D与文章内容一致，因此为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 文章中提到：'It's unclear why the Queen built the zoo, but it might have been to show off her wealth and power.'

exam_questions.question_text: What do we learn about King Henry I's collection of animals in England?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It was part of the royal estate.", "B) It was a shelter for wild animals.", "C) It was the kingdom's best-equipped zoo.", "D) It was the first public exhibit of animals."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章最后提到，英国国王亨利一世约在1110年将动物收藏作为皇家领地的一部分。选项A与文章内容一致，因此为正确答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 文章中提到：'In England, King Henry I set up a collection of animals in about 1110 as part of the royal estate.'

exam_questions.options: ["A) accepted", "B) audiences", "C) building", "D) complex", "E) constitutes", "F) deputies", "G) previously", "H) revolving", "I) samples", "J) selected", "K) solemn", "L) struggle", "M) suddenly", "N) understand", "O) vary"]
exam_questions.analysis: 形容词辨析题。空格前是the kinds of，空格后是and strategic self-presentation behaviour。and连接并列成分，strategic为形容词，故空格处需填入形容词，与strategic共同修饰behaviour。由定语从句we see in adults可知，这种展示自我的行为是人们在成年人身上看到的，它具有复杂性，因为，一般而言，人越长大行为越复杂，故空格处应填入complex一词，与and后的strategic（策略性的）构成语义上的并列关系，故选D。
exam_questions.explanation: complex表示复杂的，与strategic并列修饰self-presentation behaviour

exam_questions.options: ["A) accepted", "B) audiences", "C) building", "D) complex", "E) constitutes", "F) deputies", "G) previously", "H) revolving", "I) samples", "J) selected", "K) solemn", "L) struggle", "M) suddenly", "N) understand", "O) vary"]
exam_questions.analysis: 副词辨析题。该句为比较结构，than引导比较状语从句，从句中省略了主语和be动词，完整形式可能为than [it was] ______ known。known为过去分词，此处需填入副词修饰known。New findings（新发现）暗示前后认知的差异，即现在的发现与过去的认知进行对比。代入previously，than previously known明确表达"比先前已知的要早得多"，符合语境，故为答案。
exam_questions.explanation: previously表示先前地，与new findings形成对比

exam_questions.options: ["A) accepted", "B) audiences", "C) building", "D) complex", "E) constitutes", "F) deputies", "G) previously", "H) revolving", "I) samples", "J) selected", "K) solemn", "L) struggle", "M) suddenly", "N) understand", "O) vary"]
exam_questions.analysis: 动词辨析题。空格前为want to be，空格后是动作执行者by those...，空格处需填入动词的过去分词形式，构成完整的被动语态。前句指出"儿童对社会地位的认知源于成年人"，本句通过Like grown-ups类比，说明儿童与成人有相似需求，即希望被自己仰慕的人______。admire（仰慕）暗示对象是儿童认可的权威或榜样，而前一句中提及的social standing（社会地位）关系到他人的评价与接纳。成年人渴望被社会认可，儿童同样如此，故空格处需体现"被认可、被接纳"的语义，应填入accepted。
exam_questions.explanation: accepted表示被接受、被认可，与by those they admire构成被动语态

exam_questions.options: ["A) accepted", "B) audiences", "C) building", "D) complex", "E) constitutes", "F) deputies", "G) previously", "H) revolving", "I) samples", "J) selected", "K) solemn", "L) struggle", "M) suddenly", "N) understand", "O) vary"]
exam_questions.analysis: 动词辨析题。空格前的what在从句中作主语，空格后是宾语，空格处需填入谓语动词。前一句提到"互动体验可以为儿童提供机会"，此处的机会指"让他们了解是什么______理想的声誉"。代入选项可知，constitutes（构成，组成）符合此处语境，句意为"让他们了解是什么构成了理想的声誉"。
exam_questions.explanation: constitutes表示构成、组成，与a desirable reputation搭配

exam_questions.options: ["A) accepted", "B) audiences", "C) building", "D) complex", "E) constitutes", "F) deputies", "G) previously", "H) revolving", "I) samples", "J) selected", "K) solemn", "L) struggle", "M) suddenly", "N) understand", "O) vary"]
exam_questions.analysis: 动名词辨析题。空格前为介词for，空格后是名词短语good reputation，介词后接动词时需用动名词形式，因此空格处需填入动名词，构成目的状语结构"for+动名词+宾语"。前面部分提及"了解是什么构成了理想的声誉"，然后用and连接空格所在的并列部分，进一步说明维护声誉的策略。代入选项可知，building"建立，构建"符合此处语境，句意为"在社交环境中哪些策略能有效树立良好的声誉"。前后文形成逻辑链条，即先认知"声誉的要素组成"，再掌握"声誉的树立方法"。
exam_questions.explanation: building表示建立、构建，与a good reputation搭配

exam_questions.options: ["A) accepted", "B) audiences", "C) building", "D) complex", "E) constitutes", "F) deputies", "G) previously", "H) revolving", "I) samples", "J) selected", "K) solemn", "L) struggle", "M) suddenly", "N) understand", "O) vary"]
exam_questions.analysis: 动词辨析题。空格前是情态动词will，空格后是名词短语their behaviour，故空格处应填动词原形。前一句指出"五岁儿童不仅已具备声誉意识，还会通过策略性行为来改变其外界形象"。本句承接alter their outward image，说明他们会通过调整行为来达成不同的目的。vary有"改变"之意，符合此处语境，且与alter形成语义复现。
exam_questions.explanation: vary表示改变、调整，与their behaviour搭配

exam_questions.options: ["A) accepted", "B) audiences", "C) building", "D) complex", "E) constitutes", "F) deputies", "G) previously", "H) revolving", "I) samples", "J) selected", "K) solemn", "L) struggle", "M) suddenly", "N) understand", "O) vary"]
exam_questions.analysis: 动词辨析题。空格前是宾语从句的主语children，空格后是and use... and连接并列成分，use为动词原形，故空格处应填入动词原形，与use并列，充当谓语。前半句是while引导的让步状语从句，意为"尽管我们知道成年人会运用五花八门的特质进行印象管理"，由此可推测，主句要表达的意思应该是，但不知道儿童是否懂得或运用类似的策略进行印象管理。结合各选项及空格后的and use可知，空格处应填入understand，该词与use（运用）形成认知递进，即先理解规律，再付诸实践。故答案为understand。
exam_questions.explanation: understand表示理解、明白，与use并列作谓语

exam_questions.options: ["A) accepted", "B) audiences", "C) building", "D) complex", "E) constitutes", "F) deputies", "G) previously", "H) revolving", "I) samples", "J) selected", "K) solemn", "L) struggle", "M) suddenly", "N) understand", "O) vary"]
exam_questions.analysis: 名词辨析题。空格位于句末，其前面为形容词different，故空格处应填名词。此句意为"不同特质在不同情境下对不同______具有不同价值"。代入选项可知，audiences符合此处语境，此处并非指"观众"，而是引申为"社交场景中的观察方"，如老师、同伴、家长等。
exam_questions.explanation: audiences表示观众、观察者，这里指不同的社交对象

exam_questions.options: ["A) accepted", "B) audiences", "C) building", "D) complex", "E) constitutes", "F) deputies", "G) previously", "H) revolving", "I) samples", "J) selected", "K) solemn", "L) struggle", "M) suddenly", "N) understand", "O) vary"]
exam_questions.analysis: 动词辨析题。空格位于句末，其前面是宾语从句的主语they，空格处应填谓语动词。where... succeed和where they ______是consider的并列宾语从句，故空格处所填词与succeed并列，需填入动词原形。前半句讨论成功控制声誉的环节，后半句应指向失败或难以控制的环节。该词与succeed形成对比，体现研究的客观性，既肯定儿童的策略性能力，也指出其可能存在的认知局限。struggle在此取"艰难应对"之意，符合语境，故为答案。
exam_questions.explanation: struggle表示艰难应对、挣扎，与succeed形成对比

exam_questions.options: ["A) accepted", "B) audiences", "C) building", "D) complex", "E) constitutes", "F) deputies", "G) previously", "H) revolving", "I) samples", "J) selected", "K) solemn", "L) struggle", "M) suddenly", "N) understand", "O) vary"]
exam_questions.analysis: 副词辨析题。pop into existence（突然产生）为固定搭配，故空格处需填入副词，修饰动词pop。前文提出问题"在五岁之前会发生什么？"，本句用don't否定了"孩子们在踏入幼儿园的第一天就______形成了声誉的观念"的情况，又根据后文提到的问题"更早的时候发生了什么呢？"，可知儿童形成有关声誉的观念并非是一蹴而就的。suddenly"突然地"符合此处语境，故为答案。
exam_questions.explanation: suddenly表示突然地，修饰pop into existence

exam_questions.question_text: During the course of preparing for Design Ventura, teachers receive training and support while students get tutoring from designers.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。由题干关键词是During the course、teachers、training and support、students、tutoring from designers定位到H段。H段倒数第二句提到，在此过程中，教师会接受培训并获得支持，学生则可以获得设计师的辅导。题干是对该句的同义转述，其中During the course of preparing for Design Ventura对应原文中的Along the way, teachers receive training and support对应原文中的there is training and support for teachers, students get tutoring from designers对应原文中的tutoring for students from designers，故答案为H。
exam_questions.explanation: H段倒数第二句：'Along the way there is training and support for teachers and tutoring for students from designers.'

exam_questions.question_text: A visit to the Design Museum shop in London can reduce the designers' fears about the future supply of talents educated in Britain.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。由题干关键词是visit和the Design Museum shop in London定位到C段。C段第一句提到，然而，如果这些设计师在今年早些时候去过伦敦设计博物馆的商店，或许就能减少他们的担忧。题干是对该句的同义转述，其中visit和the Design Museum shop in London是原词复现，题干中的can reduce the designers' fears对应原文中的their fears may have been eased，而原文中的their fears指的是C段第一句提到的内容，即许多其他设计师和建筑师也对英国公司未来本土人才的供应表示担忧，故答案为C。
exam_questions.explanation: C段第一句：'However, if these designers had visited the Design Museum shop in London earlier this year their fears may have been eased.'

exam_questions.question_text: One of Design Ventura's judges says the competition adds vigour to the standard curriculum in schools.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。由题干关键词是One of Design Ventura's judges和curriculum定位到L段。L段第一句提到了竞赛评委之一克利弗。第三句引述了克利弗的原话"鉴于当前设计教育在常规课程中的占比有限，我全力支持像'设计冒险家'这样的竞赛——它有助于让标准课程变得生动有趣"，题干是对第一句和第三句的概括与转述，其中One of Design Ventura's judges和competition是原词复现，adds vigour to the standard curriculum in schools对应原文中的helps to bring the standard curriculum to life，故答案为L。
exam_questions.explanation: L段第三句：'Now that design education is limited in the curriculum, I'm all in favour of competitions such as Design Ventura, which helps to bring the standard curriculum to life.'

exam_questions.question_text: Enrollment in Design and Technology decreased by nearly ten percent last year in the UK.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。由题干关键词是Design and Technology、decreased by nearly ten percent和last year定位到A段。A段提到，最近，英国一家顶尖的设计联合会警告称，英国可能会面临创意技能短缺的问题，因为最新的数据显示，学习"设计与技术"课程的学生人数下降了近10%。题干是对该句的同义转述，其中Design and Technology和last year是原词复现，decreased by nearly ten percent与原文中的a drop of almost 10 percent同义，Enrollment in Design and Technology与原文中的students studying Design and Technology同义，故答案为A。
exam_questions.explanation: A段第一句：'Recently, a leading design federation in the UK warned that the UK could face a creative skills shortage, after the latest figures revealed a drop of almost 10 percent in students studying Design and Technology.'

exam_questions.question_text: Participation of ninth graders in Design Ventura can motivate them to choose design technology as their subject.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。由题干关键词是Participation of ninth graders、Design Ventura、motivate和choose... as their subject定位到M段。M段的引语中的第二句提到，我们发现，如果学生在九年级时参加了"设计冒险家"竞赛，可能会促使他们在后续普通中等教育阶段选修设计技术这门课程。题干是对该句的同义转述，其中Participation of ninth graders in Design Ventura对应原文中的pupils take part in Design Ventura in Year Nine, motivate对应原文中的trigger, choose design technology as their subject对应原文中的opt for it at General Certificate of Secondary Education, 故答案为M。
exam_questions.explanation: M段第二句：'We find that if pupils take part in Design Ventura in Year Nine it can be the trigger which leads them to opt for it at General Certificate of Secondary Education.'

exam_questions.question_text: Design Ventura is welcomed by teachers because it helps to prove the worth of design as a school subject.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。由题干关键词是welcomed by teachers和design as a school subject定位到G段。G段最后一句提到，教师们喜欢这个竞赛，因为它培养的技能都是可在学科间迁移的，有助于证实设计学科的价值。题干是对该句的同义转述，其中teachers和as a... subject是原词复现，is welcomed by与原文中的like同义，helps to prove the worth of对应原文中的helps to validate the value of，故答案为G。
exam_questions.explanation: G段最后一句：'Teachers like it because the skills are all transferable and it helps to validate the value of design as a subject.'

exam_questions.question_text: The schools don't have to pay anything to take part in the Design Ventura competition.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。由题干关键词是schools、don't have to pay anything和to take part in the Design Ventura competition定位到K段。K段开头提到，学校参加"设计冒险家"竞赛无需花费任何费用。题干是对该句的同义转述，其中schools和Design Ventura是原词复现，don't have to pay anything对应原文中的costs... nothing, to take part in与原文中的to participate in同义，故答案为K。
exam_questions.explanation: K段开头：'It costs the schools nothing to participate in Design Ventura.'

exam_questions.question_text: Participants in Design Ventura are challenged to create sustainable and marketable products.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。由题干关键词是challenged to、sustainable和marketable products定位到D段。D段第二句中提到，这项竞赛面向13至16岁的学生，通过挑战他们为设计博物馆的商店开发兼具创意性、可持续性与商业可行性的新产品……题干是对该句相关内容的同义转述，其中challenged对应原文中的challenging, create... products对应原文中的develop... product, sustainable and marketable对应原文中的sustainable and commercially feasible, 故答案为D。
exam_questions.explanation: D段第二句：'which brings the business of design to life for students aged 13 to 16 by challenging them to develop a new creative, sustainable and commercially feasible product for the Design Museum shop'

exam_questions.question_text: Students benefit from Design Ventura because they can learn about budgeting and marketing in addition to game design.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。由题干关键词是learn about budgeting and marketing和game design定位到J段。J段开头提到，"这项竞赛真正实用的一点，"家里坎说，"在于它具有商业元素——因为获奖作品会真正上市销售，因此几个参赛的男生不仅需要设计游戏，还必须学习预算和营销知识。"题干是对该句的同义转述，其中learn about budgeting and marketing是原词复现，benefit from对应原文中的really useful things, in addition to对应原文中的as well as, game design与designing their game同义，故答案为J。
exam_questions.explanation: J段开头：'is that there's a commercial element because the product is going on sale for real and the boys had to learn about budgeting and marketing, as well as designing their game.'

exam_questions.question_text: According to an officer of the Creative Industries Federation, there is difficulty now in recruiting engineers in the UK.
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。由题干关键词是Creative Industries Federation、recruiting和engineers定位到B段。B段最后提到，他（即本段开头提到的创意产业联合会首席执行官）认为，同样需要创新和技术能力相结合的工程行业也存在招聘难题。题干是对该句的同义转述，其中an officer of the Creative Industries Federation对应原文中的Chief executive... of the Creative Industries Federation, there is difficulty now in recruiting engineers与原文中的Engineering... has recruitment problems同义，故答案为B。
exam_questions.explanation: B段最后一句：'Engineering, which requires a similar mix of creative and technical skills, also has recruitment problems.'

exam_questions.question_text: What do we learn from new research about pandas?
exam_questions.options: ["A) They are losing habitat due to the building of roads and houses.", "B) They have stopped seeking new mates for reproduction.", "C) They may not adapt to the fragmentation of their habitat.", "D) They may cease to exist as a result of enjoying too good a life."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章第一段第一句明确指出新研究表明，熊猫可能因生活得过于舒适而面临灭绝风险。选项D与原文意思一致，故选D。
exam_questions.explanation: 第一段第一句：'New research suggests that pandas may be at risk of dying out because they are too comfortable.'

exam_questions.question_text: What can we conclude from the new research by scientists at Michigan State University?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Environmentalists' long-time belief regarding panda conservation may be misleading.", "B) Housing development near pandas' homes may threaten their survival.", "C) Pandas' natural habitats are becoming less suitable for reproduction.", "D) The increased panda population is attributed to the fragmentation of their habitat."]
exam_questions.analysis: 推理判断题。文章第二段提到，环保主义者长期以来一直认为栖息地碎片化会威胁熊猫生存，但新研究（由第三段首句可知，该研究是由密歇根州立大学的科学家开展的）表明适度的不适与栖息地碎片化可能有助于保护熊猫种群，这说明传统观点可能具有误导性，选项A与原文逻辑一致，故选A。
exam_questions.explanation: 第二段：'Environmentalists have long believed that building roads or homes near the bears may threaten their survival... But the new research suggests that a "modest degree of discomfort and fragmentation" may actually help preserve panda populations.'

exam_questions.question_text: What is the experts' conclusion regarding pandas?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It is urgent to provide an ideal habitat for them to thrive.", "B) It is very important to preserve their genetic diversity.", "C) Their chances of finding new mates have a lot to do with their habitat.", "D) Their environment for survival has been continuously worsening."]
exam_questions.analysis: 推理判断题。由第三段第二句可知，研究得出结论：若熊猫发现栖息地过于舒适，它们就不会迁徙寻找新配偶，从而导致关键的遗传多样性缺失。这说明专家认为熊猫寻找新配偶的机会与栖息地舒适度密切相关，选项C与原文表述含义一致，故选C。
exam_questions.explanation: 第三段第二句：'It concluded that pandas fail to wander off in search of new mates if they find their habitat too comfortable, resulting in a lack of vital genetic diversity.'

exam_questions.question_text: What can we infer from the passage about the Goldilocks principle?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It needs to be confirmed by more studies on pandas.", "B) It applies to the preservation of pandas too.", "C) It has implications for future panda research.", "D) It can be used to locate the right spot for pandas."]
exam_questions.analysis: 推理判断题。文章第六段第一句明确提到，新研究结论与"金发姑娘原则"不谋而合，该原则强调事物的量需恰到好处，而目前面的内容可知密歇根州立大学的新研究结论有助于熊猫物种的保护，由此可推断"金发姑娘原则"也适用于熊猫保护，故选B。
exam_questions.explanation: 第六段第一句：'Their conclusions about what The Guardian described as this "sweet spot" are in line with the so-called Goldilocks principle.'

exam_questions.question_text: What can the new findings do according to Professor Sillero?
exam_questions.options: ["A) Help discover new ways for the conservation of pandas.", "B) Help remove pandas from the list of endangered species.", "C) Shed light on the conservation of most large meat-eating animals.", "D) Show the complexity of interactions between humans and animals."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。根据文章前面段落的内容可知，密歇根州立大学的新研究发现适度的不适与栖息地碎片化实际上可能有助于保护熊猫种群，而文章倒数第三段中西莱罗教授表示，这项新发现的影响范围不止在熊猫保护领域。言外之意，该研究结论不仅适用于熊猫种群，还适用于其他种群。在下一段中，西莱罗教授对其言论做了进一步解释，概括起来就是，大多数大型肉食动物都在存在日益碎片化的环境中，这可能促使它们更易被分散或迁徙，从而可能提升其遗传连通性并增强其种群存续能力。也就是说，新发现不仅会促进熊猫物种保护，也为大型肉食动物保护提供了启示。由此可知，本题应选C。
exam_questions.explanation: 倒数第三段：'Claudio Sillero... told the newspaper that the new findings could have implications beyond panda conservation.'

exam_questions.question_text: What does the passage say about people born with natural talents?
exam_questions.options: ["A) They seem to outdo others without hard work.", "B) They appear to know all the secrets to success.", "C) They feel it only too logical to succeed.", "D) They are bound to excel effortlessly."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章第一段第一句指出，天赋异禀的人似乎无需真正努力就能出类拔萃，选项A与原文表述的含义一致，故为答案。
exam_questions.explanation: 第一段第一句：'With those born with natural talents, it feels as if they excel without really trying.'

exam_questions.question_text: What does Duckworth say about talent?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It is a new concept much too overrated.", "B) It proves necessary for big achievements.", "C) It plays a lesser role in one's success.", "D) It is a guarantee for real success in life."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章第二段第一句提到，达克沃斯认为天赋或许被高估了，若想获得真正的成功，需要的是坚毅，也就是激情与毅力的完美融合。即便拥有天赋，缺乏坚毅也终将一事无成。可见她强调努力比天赋更重要，即天赋在成功中作用较小。C项与原文逻辑一致，故选C。
exam_questions.explanation: 第二段：'She introduces a new concept that talent may be overrated, and if you want real success, what you need is grit the perfect combination of passion and persistence. Even if you have natural talent it's nothing without grit.'

exam_questions.question_text: What does the passage say about people thinking of attaining success?
exam_questions.options: ["A) They are puzzled how to present their best to the employer.", "B) They are burdened by their expectation of perfection.", "C) They will try hard to land a job that fits their skills best.", "D) They will find themselves lacking in all the skills they need."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章第三段第三句提到，当我们思考如何获得成功时——无论是争取一份工作，还是学习一项新技能——思维总会被"必须先掌握的所有知识"压得喘不过气，也就是说人们追求成功时，力争在各方面都做到完美，从而产生负担，B项含义与原文表述一致，故选B。
exam_questions.explanation: 第三段第三句：'When we think about attaining success — whether it's landing that job or learning that new skill — our thoughts are immediately burdened by all the things we must first learn.'

exam_questions.question_text: How does the author think grit can be helpful to us?
exam_questions.options: ["A) It allows us to know what we are good at.", "B) It opens our eyes to new opportunities.", "C) It focuses our attention on what we do.", "D) It lets us reconsider the goals to achieve."]
exam_questions.analysis: 细节辨认题。文章第四段第三句指出，坚毅让我们重新思考自己的目标，选项D与原文意思一致，故选D。
exam_questions.explanation: 第四段第三句：'Grit allows us to redefine our goals.'

exam_questions.question_text: What message does Duckworth try to convey in her book Grit?
exam_questions.options: ["A) We should perfect ourselves to ensure success.", "B) We should stay persistent even in face of failures.", "C) We can never master a skill without constant practice.", "D) We can never expect to reach our goals without passion."]
exam_questions.analysis: 主旨大意题。由第五段最后两句可知，达克沃斯宣告：一切皆有可能，若初次尝试失败，就带着坚毅再试一次。全文在介绍达克沃斯《坚毅》一书，所以全文最后两句就是在总结她在《坚毅》一书中要传递的信息，即面对失败仍需坚持，选项B精准概括了这一观点，故选B。
exam_questions.explanation: 第五段最后两句：'She is saying it is possible that you can accomplish anything. If at first you fail, then try one more time with grit.'

exam_questions.question_text: Translate the Chinese passage into English.
exam_questions.correct_answer: Yuan Longping, known globally as the "Father of Hybrid Rice", and his research team overcame numerous challenges to successfully develop a super hybrid rice variety. This technology has been universally recognized as a tremendous success. Through the application of this technology, the rice exhibits stronger drought and disease resistance, adapts to diverse climatic and soil conditions, and achieves a 20-30% increase in yield. The super hybrid rice is also more nutritious and has a superior taste. Currently, the technology has been widely applied in many countries, making significant contributions to global food security.
exam_questions.analysis: 翻译题目，需要学生将中文段落准确翻译成英文，注意语法、词汇和句式结构的正确性
exam_questions.explanation: 考查学生的汉译英能力，包括词汇选择、语法结构、句式转换和语言表达的准确性
